title: South Entrance
listingDescription: Welcome to Yosemite National Park! Prepare to let your curiosity guide you to new places. Pick up a map and brochure as you enter your national park. The park entrance fee can be paid upon arrival. Park passes can be purchased here, and park brochures may be available.
bodyText:
Welcome to Yosemite National Park! The South Entrance is a fee station located along Wawona Road, the continuation of Highway 41 within the park.

Visitors can pay the park entrance fee, show their parks pass, or purchase a pass as they enter the park. Park brochures may be available. Entrance stations at Yosemite do not accept cash. Learn more about entrance fees and passes. 

Seasonal Information

Yosemite National Park is open 24 hours per day, 365 days per year (conditions permitting).

From spring through fall, you are likely to experience congestion in Yosemite Valley and at park entrances. Be prepared for delays, especially in afternoons and on weekends. Plan accordingly and use restrooms when available. It is best to arrive early in the morning or in the late afternoon to find parking and avoid traffic delays.

Accessibility

Request a park accessibility guide here.

images.title: South Entrance
images.altText: Three small wooden buildings at the entrance with the American flag on a pole
images.caption: South Entrance

title: Stoneman Meadow
listingDescription: With views of Half Dome, North Dome, Upper Yosemite Fall, and Washington Column, Stoneman Meadow is an excellent spot for sunset and for appreciating the area's rich meadow ecology. In mid-to-late summer, watch Hooker's evening primrose blossoms open at dusk, attracting sphinx moths to their bright yellow blooms.
bodyText:
With views of Half Dome, North Dome, Upper Yosemite Fall, and Washington Column, Stoneman Meadow is an excellent spot for sunset and for appreciating the area's rich meadow ecology.

In mid-to-late summer, watch Hooker's evening primrose blossoms open at dusk, attracting sphinx moths to their bright yellow blooms.

Tips & Seasonal Information

Stay on designated paths and boardwalks to protect fragile meadow ecosystems!

This area can be reached year-round. Boardwalks may be very slippery from frost or snow in winter.

To reach this meadow, take the free shuttle to Curry Village, or park your vehicle in nearby Curry Village or in designated roadside parking. Parking or driving on vegetation is prohibited.

Accessibility

Wheelchair accessible paved paths and boardwalks are available in and around this meadow.

images.title: Stoneman Meadow
images.altText: A grassy, open area with granite cliffs above
images.caption: Stoneman Meadow in summer

title: Summit Meadow
listingDescription: In the summer, an explosion of color lure people toward this sub-alpine meadow to delight in the spectacular display of wildflowers.
bodyText:
In the summer, this sub-alpine meadow to delight features a spectacular display of wildflowers. To protect fragile meadow ecosystems, please stay out of the meadow.

Parking is extremely limited.

Tips & Seasonal Information

A vault toilet is located next to the parking area for this meadow.

This area is only reachable by car when Glacier Point Road is open, which is typically from approximately late May through October or November. Overnight parking is prohibited beginning October 15. For current road and weather information, call 209/372-0200 (press 1, then 1).

Accessibility

There are no designated accessible parking spaces. The meadow can be viewed from the paved parking area.

images.title: Summit Meadow
images.altText: Grassy meadow with purple wildflowers in bloom
images.caption: Summit Meadow

title: Sunrise Lakes Trailhead
listingDescription: If you're seeking a challenge with a picturesque payoff, Sunrise Lakes won't disappoint. Indeed, a beautiful place to see a sunrise, the lakes at Sunrise reflect the colors in the sky as well as the domed peaks that surround it. There is also a High Sierra Camp located at Sunrise, whose origin dates back to 1916, the earliest days of the National Park Service.
bodyText:
Sunrise Lakes

Indeed, a beautiful place to see sunrise, the lakes at Sunrise reflect the colors in the sky as well as the domed peaks that surround it. A short distance from the lakes, the Sunrise High Sierra Camp faces east for sunrise views. Reservations are required for lodging at all High Sierra Camps.

Distance: 10.4 mi (16.7 km) round-trip
Elevation gain: 1,300 ft (396 m)
Time estimate: 6-8 hours

Clouds Rest

Situated at 9,926 ft above sea level, the summit of Clouds Rest affords hikers spectacular, 360-degree views of Tenaya Canyon, Yosemite Valley, and countless high Sierra peaks. The final ascent toward the summit follows a narrow granite ridgeline. Caution: stay off this summit and ridgeline during thunderstorms or when wet.

Distance: 14 mi (22.5 km) round-trip
Elevation gain: 2,300 ft (700 m)
Time estimate: 8-10 hours

Tips & Seasonal Information

Pets and bicycles are not allowed on hiking trails. Vault toilets are available at this trailhead. A composting toilet is available seasonally at Sunrise High Sierra Camp (this is not on the route to Clouds Rest).

This trailhead is only reachable by vehicle when Tioga Road is open, typically late May or early June to sometime in October or November.

Tioga Road closes after the first significant snowfall. Overnight parking on this road, including this trailhead, ends October 15. For current road and weather information, please call 209/372-0200 (press 1, then 1).

images.title: Clouds Rest
images.altText: A narrow granite ridgeline extends toward the horizon and many distant peaks
images.caption: Ridgeline near Clouds Rest summit

title: Swinging Bridge
listingDescription: Experience a view like none other while standing on the Swinging Bridge. Get a glimpse of Yosemite Falls and its reflection in the Merced River during the day or by full moon at night. The first thing you may notice about Swinging Bridge is that it does not swing. Multiple years of high flood waters took its toll on the previous swinging bridge, until it was finally replaced with a permanently fixed bridge after being damaged in the 1964 flood. Picnic tables and grills are co
bodyText:
Picnic tables, grills, seasonal river access, and a walking/biking path are available at this scenic spot along the Merced River with views of Yosemite Falls and the surrounding cliffs. The adjacent beach offers access to the Merced River when water levels are low. Vault toilets are available in the area. Parking is extremely limited.

Despite its name, Swinging Bridge does not swing. Multiple floods repeatedly damaged the former swinging bridge, until it was replaced with a permanently fixed bridge after the 1964 flood.

The paved pathway connects to nearby points of interest and visitor services such as Cook's Meadow, Yosemite Chapel, Yosemite Valley Lodge, and Lower Yosemite Fall trail.

Tips & Seasonal Information

This picnic area is open year-round.

Swift-moving, cold water is very dangerous and even deadly. Anytime the river is flowing strongly, such as in spring, stay away from the water.

Diving or jumping from the bridge is prohibited at all times.

Yosemite Falls is a seasonal waterfall fed by snowmelt; it is usually completely dry by late summer then is sometimes revived again by late fall storms.

Wildlife Safety

  • Keep your distance from animals, even if they approach you.
  • Never feed wild animals.
  • Dispose of trash in bear-proof trash cans or dumpsters.
  • While enjoying your picnic, keep your food, trash, and other scented items within arm's reach.
  • If a bear approaches, yell as loudly as possible to scare the bear away.

Accessibility

The Swinging Bridge Picnic Area features accessible picnic tables with extended tops, accessible vault toilets, and grills. The picnic area is unpaved but flat. The paths leading to both the picnic area and bridge can be reached by paved, mostly flat walkways. The beach is not wheelchair accessible. Designated accessible parking spaces are available.

images.title: View from Swinging Bridge
images.altText: Visitors on the beach and in the water below a granite cliff with a dry waterfall
images.caption: View of the Merced River and Yosemite Falls from Swinging Bridge in late summer

title: Tenaya Lake
listingDescription: Caught between immense granite domes and clear Sierra Nevada sky, Tenaya Lake is the largest lake in Yosemite's frontcountry. Because of its remarkable scenic qualities, its inviting blue water, and its proximity to Tioga Road, Tenaya Lake is one of the most popular destinations for summer visitors in Yosemite. It is quite popular for picnicking, swimming, and canoeing. Tenaya Lake was named after Chief Tenaya, who was the last chief of the Yosemite Indians.
bodyText:
Situated amidst granite domes and peaks, Tenaya Lake is the largest lake in Yosemite's frontcountry. Tenaya Lake is one of the most popular summer destinations for picnicking, swimming, and kayaking. There are several parking areas along the lake for beach access, picnic tables, and scenic views. Vault toilets are available at some parking areas.

Tenaya Lake was named after Chief Tenaya, an American Indian tribal leader living in Yosemite Valley at the time of invasion by the Mariposa Battalion.

Non-motorized watercraft such as paddleboards, kayaks, and canoes are permitted on the lake. Every person must have a personal flotation device immediately available for each occupant of the watercraft. Children under age 13 must be wearing a personal flotation device.

Seasonal Information

Tenaya Lake is only reachable by vehicle when Tioga Road is open, typically late May or early June to sometime in October or November.

Tioga Road closes after the first significant snowfall. Overnight parking on this road ends October 15. For current road and weather information, please call 209/372-0200 (press 1, then 1).

Accessibility

The east end of Tenaya Lake has designated accessible parking spaces, an accessible vault toilet, and an accessible, paved path that leads to open views of Tenaya Lake.

images.title: Tenaya Lake
images.altText: Lake with granite cliffs at its edge
images.caption: Tenaya Lake

title: Tenaya Lake Picnic Area
listingDescription: Enjoy this magnificent high-country lake surrounded by granite domes, lodgepole forests, and Yosemite's vast wilderness. Picnic tables are available at this pleasant spot near Tenaya Lake. Picnic areas are available on a first-come, first-served basis (reservations not accepted).
bodyText:
Several picnic tables are available near the eastern beach of Tenaya Lake, a short, easy walk from the parking area.

Vault toilets and trash/recycling are available in the parking area. There are no facilities in the immediate area of the picnic area or the beach.

Tips & Seasonal Information

This picnic area is only reachable by vehicle when Tioga Road is open, typically late May or early June to sometime in October or November.

Tioga Road closes after the first significant snowfall. Overnight parking on this road, including this trailhead, ends October 15. For current road and weather information, please call 209/372-0200 (press 1, then 1).

Wildlife Safety

  • Keep your distance from animals, even if they approach you.
  • Never feed wild animals.
  • Dispose of trash in bear-proof trash cans or dumpsters.
  • While enjoying your picnic, keep your food, trash, and other scented items within arm's reach.
  • If a bear approaches, yell as loudly as possible to scare the bear away.

Accessibility

This picnic area is located approximately 700 ft (215 m) from the parking area along mostly paved, wheelchair accessible paths. The final stretch is a short, flat unpaved section. Some picnic tables may only be reached by traveling over surfaces that may be uneven or sandy. The vault toilet at the parking area is wheelchair accessible. Designated accessible parking spaces are available.

images.title: Tenaya Lake picnic area
images.altText: A wood picnic table, tall trees, and a large lake visible in the distance
images.caption: Tenaya Lake picnic area

title: The Ahwahnee
listingDescription: Known for its stunning interior design and architecture, The Ahwahnee was specifically designed to highlight its natural surroundings, featuring Yosemite Falls, Half Dome, and Glacier Point.The hotel holds a historic heritage as it is listed on the National Register of Historic Places and is a National Historic Landmark. The destination of queens and presidents alike, this dis
bodyText:
Known for its stunning interior design and architecture that combines rustic and art deco influences, The Ahwahnee offers hotel rooms, suites, parlors, and cottages. Designed by architect Gilbert Stanley Underwood and completed in 1927, The Ahwahnee was built to draw more affluent visitors to Yosemite National Park. An experiment in construction methods, it was built with mostly fireproof materials, including concrete and granite textured and stained to resemble redwood.

See website for more information about the rooms and to make a reservation.

Operating Hours & Seasons

The Ahwahnee is open year-round. The front desk is staffed 24 hours a day.

Dining & Shopping

The Ahwahnee Dining Room. Fine dining serving breakfast, lunch, dinner, and Sunday brunch. Indoor seating only. Appropriate attire required for dinner. Dinner reservations strongly recommended: 209/372-1489 or OpenTable.com.

The Ahwahnee Bar. Table service, indoor and outdoor seating. Beer on tap, cocktails, and light dining for lunch and dinner.

Coffee Bar. Serving tea, espresso drinks, and brewed coffee. Order at The Ahwahnee Bar.

Sweet Shop. Snacks, sweets, wine.

Gift Shop. Gifts, Native American pottery, jewelry, clothing, books.

See website or the current issue of the Yosemite Guide for dining and shopping hours.

Accessibility

All lodging facilities in the park meet accessibility requirements. Select rooms and cottages are wheelchair accessible. Valet parking is available, and designated accessible parking spaces are located in the parking lot. A wheelchair accessible path of travel connects the hotel with the cabins.

images.title: The Ahwahnee
images.altText: A sheer cliff face serves as a backdrop behind a building made of stone and wooden planks.
images.caption: The Ahwahnee at dusk.

title: The Ahwahnee EV Charging Station
listingDescription: Located at the southwestern end of The Ahwahnee parking area, this electric vehicle (EV) charging station features six level 2 chargers. These chargers have a J1772 connector. You do not need to be a guest at The Ahwahnee to charge your vehicle, however, you must move your vehicle from the space once it is finished charging.
bodyText:
Located at the southwestern end of The Ahwahnee parking area, this electric vehicle (EV) charging station features six level 2 chargers. These chargers have a J1772 connector. You do not need to be a guest at The Ahwahnee to charge your vehicle, however, you must move your vehicle from the space once it is finished charging.

EV charging is available in Yosemite National Park at no cost, courtesy of Yosemite Hospitality. Other charging stations are available outside the park. Use the Alternative Fuels Data Center to view locations of EV charging stations in the area.

Charging stations are available 24 hours a day.

images.title: The Ahwahnee EV Charging Station
images.altText: A vehicle plugged into a charging station in a parking area with a large hotel in the background
images.caption: The Ahwahnee EV Charging Station

title: The Ansel Adams Gallery
listingDescription: Visit The Ansel Adams Gallery to explore the works of Ansel Adams, contemporary artists, or to sign up for half-day photography classes, workshops , or camera walks. From its origin in 1902 in a tent in the California Wilderness, Best's Studio, now operating as The Ansel Adams Gallery, has evolved into a center that celebrates the arts and grandeur of our environment.
bodyText:
Experience a variety of fine arts, books, art supplies, handcrafts, and an outstanding collection of Ansel Adams’ original photographs. Originally known as Best's Studio, this family-owned business has operated in Yosemite Valley since 1902.

The Ansel Adams Gallery offers a variety of both free and paid photography education programs. Learn more and register at the gallery or on the website.

Operating Hours & Seasons

Open daily year-round. See the Yosemite Guide or gallery website for current hours.
Closed Thanksgiving and Christmas Day.

Accessibility

The gallery's main floor is accessible by ramp at the front. The upper level is accessible by an outside path (with a short slope of 8 percent) or by steps inside.

images.title: The Ansel Adams Gallery
images.altText: A single story building with a large covered porch and log details extending at its corners
images.caption: The Ansel Adams Gallery

title: The Cascades Picnic Area
listingDescription: During the spring, torrents of water from melted snow thunder over a precipice to form The Cascades waterfall. Bring a picnic and enjoy it while listening to the water of The Cascades and the Merced River.Picnic tables and grills are available at this scenic spot near the Cascades waterfall and along the Merced River. Hours :Year-round Getting Here :Located on El Portal Road (Highway 140), between the Arch Rock Entrance and Yosemite Valley. Rules & Regulations :Picnic areas
bodyText:
About 10 minutes away from Yosemite Valley by car, picnic tables and grills are available at this scenic spot near the Cascades waterfall, Cascade Creek, and the Merced River. Mature canyon live oaks and ponderosa pines provide shade across the picnic area. The Cascades waterfall, situated just across the road, is a lesser-visited waterfall that is stunning in spring as winter's snow melts into the creek.

Tips & Seasonal Information

This picnic area is open year-round. A vault toilet is available at the parking area.

Swift-moving, cold water is very dangerous and even deadly. Anytime the river and creeks are flowing strongly, such as in spring, stay away from the water.

Wildlife Safety

  • Keep your distance from animals, even if they approach you.
  • Never feed wild animals.
  • Dispose of trash in bear-proof trash cans or dumpsters.
  • While enjoying your picnic, keep your food, trash, and other scented items within arm's reach.
  • If a bear approaches, yell as loudly as possible to scare the bear away.

Accessibility

The Cascades Picnic Area features accessible picnic tables with extended tops, accessible restrooms, and grills that are accessible. Designated accessible parking spaces are available nearby. The pathway to the picnic area is on a slight incline and unpaved. The path may be uneven or slightly rocky in places.

images.title: The Cascades Picnic Area
images.altText: A picnic table and grill in a dirt area surrounded by trees
images.caption: The Cascades Picnic Area

title: Tioga Pass Entrance
listingDescription: Welcome to Yosemite National Park! Prepare to let your curiosity guide you to new places. Pick up a map and brochure as you enter your national park. The park entrance fee can be paid upon arrival. Park passes can be purchased here, and park brochures may be available.
bodyText:
Welcome to Yosemite National Park! The Tioga Pass entrance is a fee station located on Tioga Road, the continuation of Highway 120 from the east. Situated at 9,945 feet (3,031 m) above sea level, Tioga Pass is located along the crest of the Sierra Nevada mountains.

Visitors can pay the park entrance fee, show their parks pass, or purchase a pass as they enter the park. Park brochures may be available. Entrance stations at Yosemite do not accept cash. Learn more about entrance fees and passes. 

Seasonal Information

Tioga Road is closed seasonally from approximately November through May or June. Check road status or call 209/372-0200 (press 1, then 1) for current road conditions.

When Tioga Road is closed, it is not possible to drive to Tuolumne Meadows or enter Yosemite National Park from the east. All other park entrances, including those accessed via Highway 120 from the west, Hetch Hetchy, Highway 140, and Highway 41, remain open all year.

From spring through fall, you are likely to experience congestion in Yosemite Valley and at park entrances. Be prepared for delays, especially in afternoons and on weekends. Plan accordingly and use restrooms when available. It is best to arrive early in the morning or in the late afternoon to find parking and avoid traffic delays.

Accessibility

Request a park accessibility guide here.

images.title: Tioga Pass Entrance Station
images.altText: Small wooden building with a car at the window
images.caption: Tioga Pass Entrance Station

title: Tioga Road - Cones and Needles Wayside Exhibit
bodyText: Have you ever wondered how to tell a fir from a pine? Or why you don't really see rattle snakes or giant sequoias at 9,000 feet elevation? Learn more about red firs and Yosemite's life zones and micro-climate at these wayside exhibits.

images.altText: A wayside exhibit stands beneath a tall tree.

title: Tioga Road - Disappearing Meadows Wayside Exhibit
bodyText: How and why do we seem to be losing our meadows to trees? Is that a good thing? And, are you in the midst of an ancient volcanic mountain range? Learn more at these wayside exhibits.

images.altText: A stream snakes through a meadow. Pebbles, rocks, and boulders line the bottom and outskirts of the shallow stream. Two mountain peaks rise up above treeline.

title: Tioga Road - Form Follows Fracture Wayside Exhibit
bodyText: As you drive along the Tioga Road you may notice the granite bedrock is riddled with fractures. You may even see trees taking root in the granite bedrock! How is that possible? Learn more about it at this wayside exhibit.

images.altText: A wayside exhibit stands at a scenic roadside pullout that overlooks the high country landscape.

title: Tioga Road - Glacial Moraine Wayside Exhibit
bodyText: Get a personal glimpse of a glacial moraine and learn how nature shaped Yosemite's mountains and canyons, at this wayside exhibit.

images.altText: A wayside exhibit stands next to a small hillside scattered with different sized boulders.

title: Tioga Road - High Sierra Stories Wayside Exhibit
bodyText: How do plants and animals survive at the highest elevations in the park? And, how did people travel in this area from hundreds of years ago to today? Learn more at these wayside exhibits.

images.altText: A meadow surrounds a small lake. A few mountain peaks rise up above the nearby treeline.

title: Tioga Road - Meadow Wayside Exhibit
bodyText: Learn more about the old Mono Trail, a part of a network for American Indian Trade, about the importance of Yosemite's and the Sierra Nevada snow pack, and the history of the Tioga Road, from these wayside exhibits.

images.altText: A wayside exhibit stands along a roadside pullout.

title: Tioga Road - Surviving the Crossing Wayside Exhibit
bodyText: Who were the first non-Indians to pass through this area, and how did they survive? Learn more from this wayside exhibit.

images.altText: A wayside exhibit stands near a roadside pullout.

title: Tunnel View
listingDescription: The iconic Tunnel View overlook has captured the awe of visitors for more than 75 years. Tunnel View provides one of the most famous views of Yosemite Valley, showcasing the immensity of the granite walls that surround Yosemite Valley and providing a classic view of El Capitan, Half Dome, Sentinel Rock, Cathedral Rocks, and Bridalveil Fall. It is spectacular at sunset or after the clearing of a storm. Wawona Tunnel The construction of the Wawona Tunnel began on January 30, 19
bodyText:
Tunnel View provides one of the most famous views of Yosemite Valley, showcasing El Capitan, Half Dome, Sentinel Rock, Cathedral Rocks, and Bridalveil Fall. It is spectacular at sunset or after the clearing of a storm.

The construction of the Wawona Tunnel began on January 30, 1931, and opened to public travel on June 18, 1933. It took about 230 tons of dynamite to bore through solid granite to create this nearly mile-long tunnel. The construction of the Wawona Tunnel is considered significant in its design within the National Park System and the National Register of Historic Places.

Seasonal Information

Tunnel View is reachable by vehicle year-round.

Accessibility

Designated accessible parking spaces are available. The viewpoint can be seen from the parking area or via a short, paved walk to the pedestrian viewing area. There is a bronze tactile model of Yosemite Valley near the overlook.

images.title: Tunnel View
images.altText: Large granite monoliths in the distance with a dense conifer forest below
images.caption: Tunnel View

title: Tuolumne Grove
listingDescription: Marvel at nearly two dozen mature giant sequoias in the Tuolumne Grove of Giant Sequoias.Begin at Tuolumne Grove parking lot and follow the Old Big Oak Flat Road-one of the first roads into Yosemite Valley-steeply downhill through sugar pines and white firs. The trail drops 500 feet (150 meters) in one mile. The way down can seem much easier than the uphill return to the parking lot. The trip is moderate on the uphill portion. Within the Tuolumne Grove there is an easy, half-
bodyText:
The Tuolumne Grove of Giant Sequoias is home to about two dozen mature giant sequoias. Begin at the Tuolumne Grove parking lot and follow the former Big Oak Flat Road (now closed to all vehicles) steeply downhill through sugar pines and white firs. The trail drops 500 feet (150 meters) in one mile. The way down can seem much easier than the uphill return to the parking lot. The trip is moderate on the uphill portion. Once hikers reach the Tuolumne Grove, there is an easy, half-mile, self-guided nature trail. Parking at the trailhead is limited.

Distance: 2.5 miles (4 km) round trip
Elevation gain: 500-foot (152 m) elevation gain on return trip
Time estimate: 1-2 hours round trip

Tips

  • Bicycles are not allowed on this trail.
  • Pets are allowed on the paved trail through the grove, but not on the side trails in the grove.
  • Pit toilets are available at the trailhead parking area. There are no restrooms or water available in the grove.

Seasonal Information

The grove is open year round. Expect snowy and icy conditions in winter.

In winter, ski or snowshoe touring in Yosemite can be a magnificent experience! The Tuolumne Grove trail descends 500 feet from the trailhead to the giant sequoias. This is a popular trail both with snowshoers and hikers and is a strenuous uphill return ski.

Accessibility

This trail is not wheelchair accessible.

title: Tuolumne Meadows
listingDescription: Visit one of the largest high-elevation meadows in the Sierra Nevada, Tuolumne Meadows, and see the Tuolumne River meandering quietly through its meadow channel against a backdrop of rugged mountain peaks and glacially carved domes. Tuolumne Meadows embodies the high-country of the Sierra Nevada, with its broad sub-alpine meadows and granite domes and peaks.
bodyText:
Visit one of the largest high-elevation meadows in the Sierra Nevada, Tuolumne Meadows, and see the Tuolumne River meandering against a backdrop of rugged mountain peaks and glacially carved domes. The meadows are surrounded by stands of western white pine, mountain hemlock, and lodgepole pine. Belding's ground squirrels, mule deer, and yellow-bellied marmots are frequently seen in the meadows along with many other species of wildlife.

Experience views of Tuolumne Meadows with a short, easy walk toward Parsons Lodge. For a longer, more challenging hike through the meadow system, consider hiking toward Glen Aulin.

Tips & Seasonal Information

Tuolumne Meadows is only reachable by vehicle only while Tioga Road is open, typically from late May or early June to October or November.

Stay on official trails to protect fragile meadow ecosystems! Dogs, bicycles, and strollers are not allowed anywhere in the meadow or on hiking trails.

Accessibility

Trails toward Parsons Lodge and Soda Springs are mostly wide with gravel surfaces that may be accessible to some mobility aid users. From Parsons Lodge parking, the trail toward the lodge reaches a bridge over the Tuolumne River with several stone steps on either end of the bridge.

images.title: Tuolumne Meadows

images.caption: Tuolumne Meadows

title: Tuolumne Meadows EV Charging Station
listingDescription: Located in a park lot just west of the Tuolumne Meadows Store, this electric vehicle (EV) charging station features four level 2 chargers. These chargers have a J1772 connector.
bodyText:
Located in a parking lot just west of the Tuolumne Meadows Store, this electric vehicle (EV) charging station features four level 2 chargers. These chargers have a J1772 connector.

EV charging is available in Yosemite National Park at no cost, courtesy of Yosemite Hospitality. Other charging stations are available outside the park. Use the Alternative Fuels Data Center to view locations of EV charging stations in the area.

Charging stations are available 24 hours a day.

title: Tuolumne Meadows Grill
listingDescription: After a day of hiking the miles of trails near Tuolumne Meadows, hungry adventurers enjoy hot meals at the Tuolumne Meadows Grill. Breakfast and lunch items are served with vegetarian options. Hamburgers, hot dogs, fries, chili and more, are offered daily. The grill is located along Tioga Road, approximately a half mile east of the Tuolumne Meadows Visitor Center.
bodyText:
Fast casual breakfast and lunch with vegetarian options available. Burritos, pancakes, hamburgers, hot dogs, fries, chili and more. Outdoor seating only.

Operating Hours & Seasons

See website or current issue of the Yosemite Guide for hours. Open seasonally from mid-June through late September. Dates vary depending on the opening of the Tioga Road.

Accessibility

This facility is wheelchair accessible. Designated parking spaces are available nearby.

title: Tuolumne Meadows Lodge
listingDescription: Situated next to the Tuolumne River, this is the perfect place to settle in after hiking in Yosemite-or before embarking on an extended backpacking trip.
bodyText:
Situated next to the Tuolumne River at approximately 8,700 feet above sea level, the Tuolumne Meadows Lodge features canvas tent cabins that accommodate up to four guests. Accommodations are basic with no electricity, televisions, or WiFi.

See website for more information about the cabins and to make a reservation.

Operating Hours & Seasons

Tuolumne Meadows Lodge is open seasonally, typically mid-June to mid-September, conditions permitting.

Amenities

Showers (for guests only) and restrooms can be found in the center of the camp.

Breakfast and dinner are served at the riverside dining tent. Box lunches are also available, and can be ordered for the next day. Dinner reservations are required, and can be made by calling 209/372-8413 or in person at the front desk.

See website or the current issue of the Yosemite Guide for front desk and amenity hours.

Food Storage Requirements

Guests staying overnight at Tuolumne Meadows Lodge must follow these rules:

  • To help keep wildlife wild, cooking isn't permitted inside your tent cabin or anywhere in the lodge area.
  • Bear-proof food lockers must be used to store all scented items. This includes all food, drinks, coolers, toiletries, and trash.
  • Keep your locker closed and latched at all times, just like you would a freezer.
  • Only have the food out that you are actually using; if you're not using it, put it back into the food locker.
  • Treat your trash and recycling like food: keep it in your food locker or dispose of it in a bear-proof dumpster; do not leave it sitting out.
  • During daylight hours only, you may store food inside your car or truck (out of sight, with windows completely closed).
  • Do not leave food in a pickup truck bed or strapped to the outside of a vehicle at any time. Do not store food in your car (including trunk) or truck after dark.
  • When you check out, empty your food locker.
  • Failure to store your food properly may result in impoundment of your food or car and/or a fine of up to $5,000 and/or removal from your campsite or lodging facility.

Accessibility

All lodging facilities in the park meet accessibility requirements. Designated accessible parking spaces are available.

title: Tuolumne Meadows Wilderness Center
listingDescription: Visit the Tuolumne Meadows Wilderness Center to learn about wilderness safety, pick up wilderness permits and maps, and rent bear canisters. Wilderness permits are required year-round for any overnight stay in the Yosemite Wilderness. Permits are not required for day hikes (except if hiking to Half Dome).
bodyText:
Visit the Tuolumne Meadows Wilderness Center to learn about wilderness safety, pick up wilderness permits and maps, and rent bear canisters.

Wilderness permits are required year-round for any overnight stay in the Yosemite Wilderness. Permits are not required for day hikes (except if hiking to Half Dome). Wilderness permits are only issued to a limited number of people for each trailhead in order to provide outstanding opportunities for solitude, as required by the Wilderness Act. Learn more about obtaining a wilderness permit.

Most of Yosemite is covered in snow during winter. Before planning a wilderness trip during this time, please ensure you're prepared for winter conditions.

Operating Hours & Seasons

8 am to 5 pm daily. The Tuolumne Meadows Wilderness Center is closed seasonally from approximately October 15 to late May, depending on conditions. This wilderness center is not open when Tioga Road is closed. During this time, self-registration wilderness permits are available from outside the nearest permit station to each trailhead.

Accessibility

This facility is wheelchair accessible. There is also an accessible restroom. There are no designated accessible parking spaces.

images.title: Tuolumne Meadows Wilderness Center
images.altText: A brown building with a covered entry and a sign that says "Tuolumne Meadows Wilderness Center"
images.caption: Tuolumne Meadows Wilderness Center

title: Upper Yosemite Fall Trailhead
listingDescription: A steep climb is well rewarded with close-up views of Upper Yosemite Fall and distant views of Half Dome and other Sierra peaks. Along the hike, enjoy a bird's eye view of Yosemite Valley's meadows and the meandering Merced River. Enjoy the views from Columbia Rock, located one mile (and dozens of switchbacks) from the trailhead. The Yosemite Falls Trail is one of Yosemite's oldest historic trails, built 1873 to 1877.
bodyText:
One of Yosemite's oldest historic trails, built 1873 to 1877, the Yosemite Falls Trail leads to the top of the waterfall, which cascades 2,425 feet (739 m) above the Valley floor. This trail starts near Camp 4, along the Valley Loop Trail, and immediately climbs a series of switchbacks through oak woodland. Do not stray off of the maintained path, as you will find steep drops adjacent to the trail.

Use extreme caution when near the creek and remember you are directly above a waterfall.

Columbia Rock

Columbia Rock features views of Half Dome, Sentinel Rock, and the valley floor. From there, consider hiking another 0.5 miles (0.8 km) beyond this point for a stunning view of Upper Yosemite Fall.

Distance: 2 miles (3.2 km) round-trip
Elevation: 1,000 ft (328 m) elevation gain
Time estimate: 2-3 hours round trip

Top of Yosemite Falls

The upper switchbacks of the trail is steep and rocky but very scenic, including views of Upper Yosemite Fall with Half Dome in the background. The final portion of the hike leads to a small viewing platform where Yosemite Creek pours over the lip of the cliff.

Distance: 7.2 miles (11.6 km) round-trip
Elevation: 2,700 ft (820 m) elevation gain
Time estimate: 6-8 hours round trip

Tips & Seasonal Information

Pets and bicycles are not allowed on hiking trails. Do not shortcut switchbacks, which causes rapid trail erosion and results in injuries.

The Yosemite Falls Trail can be hiked year-round, though conditions vary depending on the season. In spring, when the waterfall is at its peak, this hike is stunning, and you may even get wet from the spray of the waterfall during a section of the hike. In summer, conditions are hot and dry, and the loose decomposed granite along the trail can be slippery. Keep in mind that by August, the waterfall is typically low or totally dry. During winter, the lower portion of this trail gets direct sunlight, so hiking can be snow-free while other trails are icy.

Columbia Rock, located one mile up the trail, is a worthwhile trip at any time of year. Beyond this point, the upper portion of this trail receives little to no sunlight in winter and can be very icy and slippery, or buried beneath feet of snow, making traction difficult. In winter, hiking in the colder early morning or late afternoon hours can be even more dangerous if the trail is icy.

images.altText: Wooden sign at trailhead
images.caption: Upper Yosemite Fall Trailhead

title: Valley Shuttle Stop 10: Cathedral Beach
listingDescription: When you arrive, park your car and enjoy the ease and convenience of our free Yosemite Valley shuttle system. Our eco-friendly shuttles will take you throughout Yosemite Valley. The Valleywide shuttle serves all stops in Yosemite Valley, including lodges, food service, campgrounds, and trailheads. Buses arrive every 12 to 22 minutes (depending on conditions) during hours of operation. You can get off and on the shuttle wherever and whenever you wish.
bodyText:
This shuttle stop is served by the Valleywide Shuttle route only. There is no covered shelter or benches at this bus stop.

Yosemite Valley shuttles are free and operate from 7 am to 10 pm daily. During hours of operation, the Valleywide Shuttle runs approximately every 22-32 minutes. No ticket is required. Passengers may board and disembark at any stop.

What's Nearby

  • Cathedral Beach picnic area
  • Valley Loop Trail

Shuttle Tips & Accessibility

  • Pets are not allowed on shuttles.
  • Allow wheelchairs to board first.
  • Collapse strollers before boarding.
  • No oversized or jogging strollers.
  • Remove baby-back carriers when seated.
  • Shuttles only stop at designated stops.
  • No smoking on shuttles.

All shuttles are accessible with wheelchair lifts and tie-downs. The maximum size for wheelchairs on shuttles is 24 inches wide x 46 inches long. Shuttle drivers will help passengers on and off shuttles or notify them of stops. If you need assistance, ask the driver.

images.caption: Valley Shuttle Stop #10: Cathedral Beach Picnic Area

title: Valley View
listingDescription: Catch a glimpse of past glaciers' exposed handiwork from Valley View, a view that highlights El Capitan, Sentinel Rock, Cathedral Rocks, and Bridalveil Fall. Valley View is a remarkable spot to soak in some of Yosemite Valley's unbelievably scenic charm. Although glaciers ended their work carving out Yosemite Valley over 14,000 years ago, the Merced River continues to shape this valley, making Yosemite a very dynamic place.
bodyText:
Take in an iconic view of El Capitan, Sentinel Rock, Cathedral Rocks, and Bridalveil Fall. Although the glaciers that carved Yosemite Valley melted about 10,000 years ago, the Merced River continues to shape this valley. In January 1997, floodwaters spilled over into the parking lot here, up to a depth of 6 feet!

Parking is extremely limited at Valley View. A vault toilet is available by crossing Northside Drive.

Seasonal Information

Located on the west end of Yosemite Valley, Valley View can be reached by vehicle year-round.

Caution: swift-moving, cold water is very dangerous and even deadly. Anytime the river is flowing strongly, such as in spring, stay away from the water.

Accessibility

There are designated accessible parking spaces available. This viewpoint is visible from the parking area.

images.title: Valley View
images.altText: View of El Capitan on the left, the river in the foreground, and Bridalveil Fall on the right
images.caption: Valley View showing El Capitan, the Merced River, and Bridalveil Fall.

title: View of Mirror Lake
listingDescription: Mirror Lake is famous for its reflections of Half Dome and Mount Watkins and is one of the few lakes that are easily accessible in Yosemite National Park. Mirror Lake is a seasonal lake on Tenaya Creek, in the shadow of Half Dome. Wayside exhibits explain the natural and cultural features of the area. Mirror Lake is in a state of transition. Sand carried by Tenaya Creek collects here, and will eventually form a meadow.
bodyText:
Mirror Lake is a seasonal lake on Tenaya Creek, famous for its reflections of Half Dome and Mount Watkins. Wayside exhibits explain the natural and cultural features of the area. When there is adequate water, the mirror effect for which the lake is named is best viewed early in the morning, when the water is still.

Tips & Seasonal Information

While you may visit this area any time of year, the lake is typically only present in spring and early summer. As summer wears on, the shallow lake gradually disappears into the sand in late summer, transforming into "Mirror Meadow." All times of year, the views of Half Dome and other nearby cliffs are remarkable.

Leashed pets, bicycles, and strollers are allowed on the paved pathways leading toward this viewpoint. Beyond that, on unpaved areas, they are prohibited. A pit toilet is available where the paved road ends, near the views of Mirror Lake.

Caution: During spring and early summer, when water levels are highest, entering the water can be dangerous. Always remember when approaching moving water to look at the conditions downstream. Waters in this area may appear ankle deep at first, but can quickly become thigh deep, and, all too often, hikers are swept into dangerous whitewater and pinned against rocks. Learn more about past experiences visitors had with swift water in this area of the park.

Accessibility 

A one-mile road, from the Mirror Lake shuttle stop, leads to this view of the lake and is easy to walk due to its paved surface. The last 1,000 feet of the trail up to the lake is on a slope from 6.6 percent to 10.6 percent.

Vehicles with a disability placard are permitted to drive up to 15 mph, with hazard lights on, to Mirror Lake. Be cautious as the road is shared with bicyclists and hikers. There are two designated accessible parking spaces available.

images.title: Mirror Lake
images.altText: Low water levels in Mirror Lake with people wading into water
images.caption: Mirror Lake during a warmer time of year when water levels are low.

title: Village Grill
listingDescription: Dine al fresco at the Village Grill, which features outside seating on an expansive deck. Grilled sandwiches, burgers, hot dogs, and veggie options are available daily. Open March - October, see website for hours. Located in eastern Yosemite Valley, in Yosemite Village, near Yosemite Village Parking. The Village Grill Deck is also located at shuttle stops #2 on the free Yosemite Valley shuttle route.
bodyText:
Counter service eatery serving grilled sandwiches, burgers, hot dogs, and veggie options. Outdoor seating only with shade umbrellas on the adjacent deck.

Operating Hours & Seasons

Open seasonally, typically March - October. See website for hours.

Accessibility

This outdoor deck and facility are wheelchair accessible. Designated accessible parking spaces are located in the Village Store 30-minute Parking Area.

title: Village Store
listingDescription: If you left something behind, or just need to stock up, we have everything you need at the Village Store.The Village Store has all the essentials you need - including groceries, meat and produce, baked goods, camping supplies, books, magazines, postcards, ice and firewood. There's also an ATM in the store. Additionally, you'll find all the souvenirs, T-shirts, sweatshirts and hats you could ever want-perfect for gifts or commemorating your Yosemite experience. Hours :Year-rou
bodyText:
The Village Store offers a large selection of groceries, grab-and-go food, camping supplies, apparel, and many other gifts and supplies.

Operating Hours & Seasons

Open year-round. See website for hours.

Accessibility

This facility is wheelchair accessible. Designated accessible parking spaces are located in the parking lot outside the store's east entrance.

title: Village Store 30-Minute Parking
listingDescription: Park in this 30-minute parking area to grab something you may have left behind, or just need to stock up on, at the Village Store. Open year-round, during store hours. See website for store hours. Located in eastern Yosemite Valley, in Yosemite Village, near Yosemite Village Parking.
bodyText:
This small parking area is for short visits to the Village Store and Welcome Center. Parking is limited to 30 minutes.

All day parking is available in Yosemite Village Parking, located just to the south of this lot.

Tips & Seasonal Information

During daylight hours only, you may store food inside your car or truck (out of sight, with windows completely closed). Do not store food in your car (including trunk) or truck after dark: use the food lockers available near the entrance to this parking area.

Do not leave food in a pickup truck bed or strapped to the outside of a vehicle at any time.

See website for Village Store hours.

Accessibility

There are designated accessible parking spaces near the entrance to the Village Store and near the path to the Village Grill Deck.

images.altText: Cars in a full parking lot, with Yosemite Falls in background
images.caption: 30-minute Village Store Parking

title: Village Store Bike Stand
listingDescription: Biking is one of the best ways to see Yosemite Valley. Yosemite Valley is flat, which makes for easy riding along our 12 miles of designated paths. Bicycles, tag-along bikes for children, trailers, and helmets are available for all ages and abilities. We also offer a select number of tandem bikes and hand-crank bikes for guests with physical limitations. Wheelchairs, electric scooters, and strollers may also be available for rent.
bodyText:
With miles of designated bike paths, Yosemite Valley offers ample opportunity for easy riding. Bicycles, tag-along bikes for children, child trailers, and helmets are available for all ages and abilities. All rental bikes are first-come, first-served. Reservations are only available for bicycles intended for people with disabilities. The Village Store bike stand has a smaller fleet of bicycles. When sold out, a larger fleet of bicycles may be found at the Curry Village bike stand or Yosemite Valley Lodge bike stand.

See website for rates.

Bicycles are not permitted on hiking trails. Ride on paved bicycle paths only. Cyclists that choose to ride on roads must ride with traffic and obey all traffic laws and signs.

Operating Hours & Seasons

See website for hours, or call 209/372-1208. Bicycle rentals are available daily spring through fall, conditions permitting.

Accessibility

A limited number of tandem and hand-crank bicycles are available for rent and may be reserved in advance by calling 209/372-1208.

This facility is wheelchair accessible. Designated accessible parking spaces are located nearby.

images.title: Village Store bike stand
images.altText: Yellow metal fencing surrounds a fleet of bicycles and a small brown structure
images.caption: Village Store bike stand

title: Wagon Shed
listingDescription: Horse-drawn stages were the practical way for visitors to experience the Yosemite, long before automobiles entered the park. Several stages from Yosemite's past are parked in this wagon shed, iconic symbols of the park's history of transportation.
bodyText: Horse-drawn stages were the practical way for visitors to experience the Yosemite, long before automobiles entered the park. Several stages from Yosemite's past are parked in this wagon shed, iconic symbols of the park's history of transportation.

title: Wapama and Rancheria Falls Trailhead
listingDescription: Hetch Hetchy is home to a diverse array of plants and animals, and in spring and early summer, home to brightly colored wildflowers. Enjoy a day hike or overnight backpacking trip (wilderness permit required) in this area at any time throughout the year.Hetch Hetchy's relatively low elevation provides for one of the longest hiking seasons in Yosemite, and the varied trails include something for everyone. Wapama Fall five-mile, round-trip hike follows the shoreline of the rese
bodyText:
Hetch Hetchy is home to a diverse array of plants and animals all times of year and is a great area for wildflowers in spring and early summer. Hetch Hetchy's relatively low elevation provides one of the longest hiking seasons in Yosemite.

The trail begins at the O'Shaughnessy Dam as hikers travel through a short tunnel blasted out of the granite. Beyond that, the trail skirts the shorelines of the reservoir with moderate up and downhill sections. The trail includes spectacular views of Tueeulala and Wapama Falls.

The trail to Rancheria Falls continues past Wapama Falls and may be done as either a long day hike (13 miles round trip) or a backpacking trip. Permits are required for all overnight hikes. Visit a wilderness center for more information.

Wapama Falls

Distance: 5 miles (8 km) round-trip
Elevation gain: 507 ft (155 m)
Time estimate: 2 hours

Rancheria Falls

Distance: 13.4 miles (21.4 km) round-trip
Elevation gain: 1909 ft (581 m)
Time estimate: 6 to 8 hours

Tips & Hours

Expect substantial mist from Wapama Falls in spring and early summer. By late summer, waterfalls in this area have typically slowed or dried out. Watch for rattlesnakes and poison oak in this area.

Pets are prohibited on all hiking trails. Swimming and boating are prohibited in Hetch Hetchy Reservoir in order to maintain a clean source of drinking water.

Unlike other areas of Yosemite, the road to Hetch Hetchy is open from sunrise to sunset only. Hetch Hetchy trailheads are not reachable by vehicle when the road is closed.

From November through March, the Hetch Hetchy Road may be subject to closures or chain requirements due to ice and snow. Call 209/372-0200 (press 1, then 1) for current road conditions.

images.title: Trailhead at Hetch Hetchy Reservoir
images.altText: A vast blue reservoir surrounded by granite peaks
images.caption: The trail to Wapama and Rancheria Falls begins at O'Shaughnessy Dam

title: Washburn Point
listingDescription: Enjoy this beautiful overlook that provides views of Half Dome and the eastern crest of the Sierra Nevada. From this vantage point, visitors will see Nevada and Vernal Falls as well as Illilouette Fall. The point is named for the Washburn brothers, who built the first road from Wawona to Yosemite Valley.
bodyText:
Enjoy this beautiful overlook that provides views of Half Dome and the eastern crest of the Sierra Nevada.

From this vantage point, visitors will see Nevada and Vernal Falls as well as Illilouette Fall. The point is named for the Washburn brothers, who were early Yosemite concessioners in the hotel and transportation businesses in the late 19th century and early 20th century. The Washburn interests funded the construction of the original Glacier Point Road in 1882.

Tips & Seasonal Information

Reachable by car when Glacier Point Road is open, typically from approximately late May through October or November.

Vehicles longer than 30 feet and vehicles pulling trailers are not allowed past Sentinel Dome parking lot and therefore cannot reach Washburn Point.

Glacier Point Road closes after the first significant snowfall. Overnight parking is prohibited beginning October 15. For current road and weather information, please call 209/372-0200.

From mid-December through March, cross-country skiers can experience this view after skiing 10.5 miles, conditions permitting.

Accessibility

There is one designated accessible parking spot at the north end of the lot.

images.title: Washburn Point
images.altText: Visitor enjoying the view with Half Dome in the background
images.caption: Washburn Point

title: Wawona Covered Bridge
listingDescription: All Yosemite-bound traffic through the Wawona area crossed the covered bridge, which was built in 1857 by Galen Clark. Clark opened the first way-station for visitors in Wawona and later became the first guardian of the Yosemite Grant. He sold his land along the river to the Washburns, and they covered the bridge in the style of their native Vermont. Its restoration was the first step in the creation of the Pioneer Yosemite History Center.As you cross the bridge, listen for t
bodyText: All Yosemite-bound traffic through the Wawona area crossed the covered bridge, which was built in 1857 by Galen Clark. Clark opened the first way-station for visitors in Wawona and later became the first guardian of the Yosemite Grant. He sold his land along the river to the Washburns, and they covered the bridge in the style of their native Vermont. Its restoration was the first step in the creation of the Yosemite History Center. As you cross the bridge, listen for the low rumble of an oncoming stage and allow your imagination to return to the days of Yosemite's pioneers.

images.altText: A bright red horse-drawn stage exits an old covered wooden bridge.

title: Wawona EV Charging Station
listingDescription: Located in the parking lot adjacent to the Wawona Store, this electric vehicle (EV) charging station features 24 level 2 chargers. Chargers have a J1772 connector with a power output of 11 kW.
bodyText:
Located in the parking lot adjacent to the Wawona Store, this electric vehicle (EV) charging station features 24 level 2 chargers. Chargers have a J1772 connector with a power output of 11 kW.

EV charging is available in Yosemite National Park at no cost, courtesy of Yosemite Hospitality. Other charging stations are available outside the park. Use the Alternative Fuels Data Center to view locations of EV charging stations in the area.

Charging stations are available 24 hours a day.

images.title: Wawona Store EV Charging Station
images.altText: A parking lot lined with electric vehicle charging ports
images.caption: Wawona Store EV Charging Station

title: Wawona Gas Station
listingDescription:
The Wawona Gas Station conveniently serves the southern end of the park for your refueling needs.

Diesel and Propane available.

Hours :
8am to 5pm, Pay at the pump 24 hours with credit or debit card.

Getting Here :
The Wawona Station is located on Wawona Road (Highway 41), at Forest Drive.

Accessibility :

Diesel and Propane available.

Hours:
8 am to 5 pm, Pay at the pump 24 hours with credit or debit card.

Getting Here:
The Wawona Station is located on Wawona Road (Highway 41), at Forest Drive.

bodyText:

Pay greens fees and rent golf clubs, pull carts, or electric carts here. The shop also provides, apparel, souvenirs, snacks, beverages, and more.

Mid-May to late October, conditions permitting.

Located in the Wawona Hotel complex, on the Wawona Road (Highway 41).

title: Wawona Grey Barn (Washburn Barn)
listingDescription: In the late 1800s, Wawona was the largest stage stop in Yosemite. After hours of bouncing and bumping along uneven dirt roads, inbound stages stopped for the night at the Wawona Hotel before making the eight-hour trip to Yosemite Valley. If a stage needed a repair before the sixteen-hour round-trip journey, the grey barn was the place to visit. The Washburns, proprietors of the Wawona Hotel, used this barn for repairing stages.

title: Wawona Hotel
listingDescription: Immersed in nature, Wawona Hotel is the perfect place to settle in during your Yosemite National Park visit.
bodyText:
As of December 2, 2024, the Wawona Hotel is closed for a comprehensive condition assessment. The closure follows a recent roof replacement project that uncovered the need for further investigation. Check the website for updates on the reopening date.

One of California's original mountain resort hotels, the Victorian-era Wawona Hotel was originally established in 1856. Accommodations consist of 50 standard hotel rooms with private bath and 54 standard hotel rooms with shared restrooms as well as an on-site dining room serving breakfast, lunch and dinner. 

Galen Clark, a former gold prospector, built the first structure on this site. He built the simple log cabin along the original trail into Yosemite Valley. Visitors would stop along the way to restock their provisions and rest before continuing their travels. From these humble beginnings, the Wawona Hotel eventually attracted many famous travelers of the day, including President Theodore Roosevelt.

Operating Hours & Seasons

Both lodging and dining room are currently closed during the comprehensive condition assessment.

Typically open March to November and several weeks in December. The front desk is staffed 24 hours a day.

The hotel dining room serves breakfast, lunch and dinner. Special holiday meals and barbecues on select weekends may be available. Seasonal amenities include a nine-hole golf course, an outdoor swimming pool, and a riding stable.

For seasonal opening dates and hours see website.

Accessibility

All lodging facilities in the park meet accessibility requirements. Designated accessible parking spaces are located on the north side of the hotel behind Hill's Studio. The hotel dining room, lobby, and restrooms are wheelchair accessible. Additionally, there are two accessible guest rooms available.

images.altText: Image of fountain in foreground and hotel in background
images.caption: Wawona Hotel and Fountain

title: Wawona Meadow Loop Trailhead
listingDescription: Take a relaxing and scenic stroll along a trail that offers breathtaking views of the Wawona Basin and gives the opportunity to see wildlife and wildflowers. Walk on the paved road across the Wawona Golf Course. Once across the golf course, take a left at the sign-posted trailhead. The trail is an unpaved fire road which loops around the meadow and returns to the Wawona Road. You will be sharing the trail with horses, bicyclists, and those that wish to hike with their pets, s
bodyText:
Take a relaxing stroll along a trail that offers breathtaking views of the Wawona Basin.

Walk on the paved road across the Wawona Golf Course. Once across the golf course, take a left at the sign-posted trailhead. The trail is an unpaved fire road which loops around the meadow and returns to the Wawona Road.

You will be sharing the trail with horses, bicyclists, and those that wish to hike with their pets, so please be courteous of others.

3.5 miles (5.6 km) round trip
1.5 to 2 hours

Hours:
Trail is open year-round

Getting Here:
Begin at the Wawona Hotel, located on the Wawona Road (Highway 41).

Rules & Regulations:
Horses, bikes, and leashed pets are permitted on the trail.

Accessibility:
This trail is not accessible.

images.altText: A wooden sign at the intersection of a trail and road reads, "Meadow Loop Trail," and has an arrow pointing to the left.

title: Wawona Picnic Area
listingDescription: Be enticed by the refreshing aroma of the forest and the sounds of the burbling river while sitting down to a picnic in Wawona. Picnic tables and grills are available at this scenic spot along the south fork of the Merced River. Hours :Year-round Getting Here :The Wawona Picnic area is located on the Wawona Road, near the Wawona Campground, about a mile north of Wawona. Rules & Regulations :Picnic areas are available on a first-come, first-served basis (reservations are not a
bodyText:
Be enticed by the refreshing aroma of the forest and the sounds of the burbling river while sitting down to a picnic in Wawona.

Picnic tables and grills are available at this scenic spot along the south fork of the Merced River.

Hours:
Year-round

Getting Here:
The Wawona Picnic area is located on the Wawona Road, near the Wawona Campground, about a mile north of Wawona.

Rules & Regulations:
Picnic areas are available on a first-come, first-served basis (reservations are not available).

Hazards & Warnings:
For your safety and that of wildlife:

Keep your distance from animals, even if they approach you.
Never feed wild animals.
Dispose of trash in bear-proof trash cans or dumpsters.
While enjoying your picnic, keep your food, trash, and other scented items within arm's reach.
If a bear approaches, yell as loudly as possible to scare the bear away.

Accessibility:
The Wawona Picnic Area features accessible picnic tables with extended tops, accessible restrooms, and grills that are accessible.

images.altText: Picnic tables are located in the shade on the banks of a river.

title: Wawona Stable
listingDescription: Beyond hiking, the best way to explore the trails at Yosemite National Park is on a mule ride or horseback riding adventure. Wawona Stable offers the only two-hour ride on mules and horses in the park. Ideal for riders of all ages and abilities, the terrain is flat and the riding is gentle.
bodyText:
The Wawona Stable is closed.

Beyond hiking, a fun way to explore the trails at Yosemite National Park is on a mule or horseback riding adventure.

Wawona Stable offers the only two-hour ride on mules and horses in the park. Ideal for riders of all ages and abilities, the terrain is flat and the riding is gentle as the ride meanders around the Wawona Meadow.

See website for times, prices, and other requirements.

Operating Hours & Seasons

Approximately May to September, conditions permitting.

Accessibility

Consult with the Wawona Stable staff to discuss potential arrangements for a gentle horse ride around the corral for someone with special needs.

title: Wawona Wilderness Center at Hill's Studio
listingDescription: Visit the Wawona Wilderness Center at Hill's Studio to learn about wilderness safety, pick up wilderness permits and maps, and rent bear canisters. Wilderness permits are required year-round for any overnight stay in the Yosemite Wilderness. Permits are not required for day hikes (except if hiking to Half Dome).
bodyText:
Visit the Wawona Wilderness Center at Hill's Studio to learn about wilderness safety, pick up wilderness permits and maps, and rent bear canisters.

Wilderness permits are required year-round for any overnight stay in the Yosemite Wilderness. Permits are not required for day hikes (except if hiking to Half Dome). Wilderness permits are only issued to a limited number of people for each trailhead in order to provide outstanding opportunities for solitude, as required by the Wilderness Act. Learn more about obtaining a wilderness permit.

Most of Yosemite is covered in snow during winter. Before planning a wilderness trip during this time, please ensure you're prepared for winter conditions.

Operating Hours & Seasons

8 am to 5 pm daily. The Wawona Wilderness Center at Hill's Studio is closed seasonally from approximately mid October through late May. During this time, self-registration wilderness permits are available from outside the nearest permit station to each trailhead.

Accessibility

Two designated accessible parking spaces and a mechanical lift are available at the rear of the studio. Use the intercom located next to the lift to request assistance from staff for operation of the lift.

images.title: Hill's Studio
images.altText: A building with a covered porch, a sign over the door reads "Hill's Studio"
images.caption: Hill's Studio

title: White Wolf Lodge
listingDescription: Set near meadows abundant with wildflowers and surrounded by pine trees, you'll find tranquility here at the remote and peaceful White Wolf Lodge.
bodyText:
White Wolf Lodge will not be operating for the 2025 season.

Set near meadows abundant with wildflowers and surrounded by pine trees, White Wolf Lodge features 24 canvas-tent cabins and four traditional wood cabins with private baths.

Guests gather morning and evening in the central dining room-a rustic wooden building with a porch that's perfect for relaxing and taking in the views. There is also a small store on site.

See website for more information about the cabins and to make a reservation.

Operating Hours & Seasons

White Wolf Lodge is open seasonally, typically mid-July to early September, conditions permitting.

The dining area, shop, and shower house are currently closed.

See website or the latest issue of the Yosemite Guide for amenity hours.

Food Storage Requirements

Guests staying overnight at White Wolf Lodge tent cabins must follow these rules:

  • To help keep wildlife wild, cooking isn't permitted inside your tent cabin or anywhere in the lodge area.
  • Bear-proof food lockers must be used to store all scented items. This includes all food, drinks, coolers, toiletries, and trash. Guests staying in wood cabins may store their food inside their cabin.
  • Keep your locker closed and latched at all times, just like you would a freezer.
  • Only have the food out that you are actually using; if you're not using it, put it back into the food locker.
  • Treat your trash and recycling like food: keep it in your food locker or dispose of it in a bear-proof dumpster; do not leave it sitting out.
  • During daylight hours only, you may store food inside your car or truck (out of sight, with windows completely closed).
  • Do not leave food in a pickup truck bed or strapped to the outside of a vehicle at any time. Do not store food in your car (including trunk) or truck after dark.
  • When you check out, empty your food locker.
  • Failure to store your food properly may result in impoundment of your food or car and/or a fine of up to $5,000 and/or removal from your campsite or lodging facility.

Accessibility

All lodging facilities in the park meet accessibility requirements. Designated accessible parking spaces are available. Wheelchair access to the front desk and dining area are via ramp located behind the main building.

images.caption: White Wolf Lodge

title: YARTS Stop: Big Oak Flat
listingDescription: Enjoy Yosemite stress free without a car. Save gas, save time, save money, by taking YARTS!The Yosemite Area Regional Transportation System (YARTS) is a regularly scheduled, fixed route, public transit system that operates year-round in the Yosemite region.YARTS provides service into Yosemite National Park and gateway communities in comfortable, air-conditioned buses. Ride YARTS to avoid traffic and safely enjoy the scenery instead of watching the road. This particular route
bodyText:
This bus stop is served by the Highway 120 West route, connecting Sonora, Jamestown, Groveland, Buck Meadows, and Yosemite Valley. This route operates May-September, seven days a week. See website for schedule.

The Yosemite Area Regional Transportation System (YARTS) is a regularly scheduled, fixed route, public transit system in the Yosemite region. YARTS provides service into Yosemite National Park and gateway communities in comfortable, air-conditioned buses.

Walk-on service is available on a first-come, first-served basis. Walk-on passengers can purchase tickets on the bus with cash (exact change only) or card. Advance reservations can be purchased online. Passengers entering the park on a YARTS bus do not need to pay the park entrance fee; it is included in the bus fare.

Bus Tips & Accessibility

  • Bags are allowed on YARTS buses, including backpacks of any size. Some backpacks may need to be stored in compartments under the passenger seating.
  • Bikes are allowed in the storage compartments under the bus, as space allows. Bicycle rentals may be available seasonally in Yosemite Valley.
  • YARTS does not pick up anywhere other than designated stops.
  • No pets are allowed to ride except for service animals.

All YARTS buses are wheelchair accessible. However, this is on a per-ride basis and is dependent upon seating locations on the bus. Passengers needing assistance while boarding may request this in advance. Passengers with disabilities as well as their companions or attendants who provide care may purchase tickets at a discounted rate.

Please contact YARTS 48 hours prior to your boarding to ensure your ride is accessible: 877/989-2787

images.title: Big Oak Flat YARTS stop
images.altText: A sign with a banner reading "YARTS" in front of a parking area
images.caption: YARTS stop at Big Oak Flat Information Station

title: YARTS Stop: Tuolumne Meadows Store
listingDescription: Enjoy Yosemite stress free without a car. Save gas, save time, save money, by taking YARTS!The Yosemite Area Regional Transportation System (YARTS) is a regularly scheduled, fixed route, public transit system that operates year-round in the Yosemite region.YARTS provides service into Yosemite National Park and gateway communities in comfortable, air-conditioned buses. Ride YARTS to avoid traffic and safely enjoy the scenery instead of watching the road. This particular route
bodyText:
This bus stop is served by the Highway 120 East/395 route, connecting Mammoth Lakes, Lee Vining, Tuolumne Meadows, and Yosemite Valley. The 120E/395 route operates July-September, seven days a week. See website for schedule.

The Yosemite Area Regional Transportation System (YARTS) is a regularly scheduled, fixed route, public transit system in the Yosemite region. YARTS provides service into Yosemite National Park and gateway communities in comfortable, air-conditioned buses.

Walk-on service is available on a first-come, first-served basis. Walk-on passengers can purchase tickets on the bus with cash (exact change only) or card. Advance reservations can be purchased online. Passengers entering the park on a YARTS bus do not need to pay the park entrance fee; it is included in the bus fare.

Bus Tips & Accessibility

  • Bags are allowed on YARTS buses, including backpacks of any size. Some backpacks may need to be stored in compartments under the passenger seating.
  • Bikes are allowed in the storage compartments under the bus, as space allows. Bicycle rentals may be available seasonally in Yosemite Valley.
  • YARTS does not pick up anywhere other than designated stops.
  • No pets are allowed to ride except for service animals.

All YARTS buses are wheelchair accessible. However, this is on a per-ride basis and is dependent upon seating locations on the bus. Passengers needing assistance while boarding may request this in advance. Passengers with disabilities as well as their companions or attendants who provide care may purchase tickets at a discounted rate.

Please contact YARTS 48 hours prior to your boarding to ensure your ride is accessible: 877/989-2787

images.caption: YARTS stop

title: Yosemite Administration Building Architecture
bodyText:
One of the first buildings constructed in the new village envisioned by Herbert Maier, Myron Hunt, and Thomas Vint, the Park Administration Building was constructed in 1924. Hunt is credited with the design of this particular building, which set the precedent for the similarly designed Post Office and Museum buildings.

Its stone first story and overhanging rustic frame second story reflect the granite canyon walls of the valley surmounted by the conifer forests above the rim.

The Administration Building is not open to public access. The Administration Building is not open to public access.
